The following quote is from an unpublished article by Stefan Shindler articulates the concept of dialectic as paradoxical thinking: 
Dialectic as paradoxical thinking frees itself from the rigid and all too often misleading confines of [analytical] either/or dogmatism and mutual exclusivism. It cultivates a unitive thinking [which compliments] separative thinking. Dialectic as here proposed is rightly praised by Kierkegaard when he says: “

children.text: Paradox is the passion of thought, and a thinker without paradox is like a lover without passion – a mediocre fellow.”

The dialectical is true thought which is neither analytical nor intuitive, neither solely discursive nor immediately apprehending; it is thought which goes beyond the abstract opposition of positive and negative, of either/or, and which therefore transcends

that opposition.” 
“Dialectic as paradoxical thinking is neither quantitative nor qualitative but combines quantitative and qualitative, analysing and synthesising; it requires of the thinker that he be critical as well as analytical, that he be comprehension as well as comprehension, that he be analysis as well as synthesis. There is a necessary interdependence between analysis and synthesis, a necessary dependence between comprehension and criticism.”

that opposition. The dialectical is that thought which brings into unity the opposites. In thinking thus we affirm the incontrovertible positive and negative, and at the same time we bring the opposites into unity.”
